ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I continued to improve my German speaking, reading, comprehension, and writing abilities.
I feel like I've gotten better at grammar and sentence structure during this class
I learned about the culture and history of German-speaking countries and regions, and I reached the level of German that this course is intended to take us up to.

I got more comfortable with speaking and reading German. I do need to work on writing with advanced grammar more, but the class helps with the different aspects (speaking, writing, listening, reading).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class had a very manageable workload this semester, which is greatly appreciated after last semester. The one way in which this course could be improved would be if there were a set of vocabulary accessible for each unit. The online textbook had this, but often our learning would go beyond these words and it would be helpful to know them in taking the test at the end of the unit.

The main complaint I have is that if you're taking this class to learn German to use in real life, you probably don't need to know words from fairy tales. Most of the units were on things that were more relevant to everyday life though, and even the fairy tale unit allowed for the reading of some fairy tales, which is nice for getting better at reading in German.

There are virtually no weaknesses to this course. I would state that the workload is a little bit too much, but even that would not be honest, since it is a 1.5 credit class. This course has plenty of strengths: most of the time, the topics are arranged in a logical sequence, feedback is abundant and incredibly quickeven though Germans complain about inefficiencies in their country, this course certainly operates with German efficiency, the instructor is absolutely fantastic and the workload is most manageable. Testing is also very reasonable and I didn't feel stressed about the biweekly tests, a situation that I believe helped me learn the language better than if I had had a final exam, for example.

Strengths: the pen pal writing was really fun, and I appreciated the modifications from last semester in terms of the asynchronous work/frequency of the textbook assignments. Well taught and Herr Pal was helpful in explaining unclear concepts. Immersed in culture as well as the language.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The three days of synchronous work and two days asynchronous worked wonderfully and really reduced zoom fatigue.
I liked how the slide shows used in class were also available on canvas, which made it easier to refer to slides when put into break out groups.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you like German or need the L2 credit, this is a great class to take. Saurabh did an excellent job at ensuring that all of us in the class were keeping up and understanding the things we were reading or speaking about. There were times where I was very lost in the conversation and Saurabh was able to lead me into the meaning of the questions I was being asked all in German.
If you're hoping to learn German, this is a good class to take.

I would under all circumstances recommend this course to a student. They would never regret taking this course if it is being taught by an instructor like Saurabh, who is so invested in his students and in German culture. I feel that the German department really wants students to enjoy their journey, so they don't force them to leave the language courses through unreasonable testing standards. Additionally, grading is fair and adequate for students aiming to achieve A2 level, which I think cannot be said of other language classes at Yale.
Yes! Built well on top of the foundations from GMAN110.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Two days out of the week, there were asynchronous assignments which could be prerecorded instructional videos, writing assignments, or other media materials.

Class was taught primarily through zoom. Breakout rooms (2-3 people) were frequently used, with the teacher going in and out of them to answer any questions. There were two projects that each lasted for about a week, in which we were working alone in groups on Monday and Wednesday without much input from the teacher, and then presenting on Friday.
